text: the customer carbon footprint tool
allows you to view the estimated carbon
footprint associated with your usage of
AWS services helping you to track
measure and review the carbon emissions
generated from your AWS
usage sustainability is both a personal
responsibility as much as it is a
business priority aws has the most
extensive global cloud infrastructure
for all of your applications and we
build with sustainability in mind
sustainability is integrated into the
way we design build and operate our AWS
infrastructure
in 2019 Amazon co-founded the climate
pledge which is our commitment to reach
net zero carbon across our global
operations by 2040 a decade ahead of the
Paris climate agreement in 2023 Amazon
met its goal 7 years early to match 100%
of the electricity consumed across our
operations including our data centers
with renewable energy according to
Bloomberg New Energy Finance Amazon is
the largest corporate purchaser of
renewable energy globally for 5 years
running and has invested billions of
dollars in more than 600 wind and solar
projects in 2024 Amazon signed four
nuclear energy agreements as part of its
plan to transition to carbon-f free
energy beyond the positive environmental
impact these projects also provide jobs
for local communities moving to AWS
cloud offers many benefits including
increased agility and innovation as well
as access to the broadest portfolio of
services a 2024 Accenture study found
that the AWS cloud is up to 4.1 times
more energy efficient than on premises
data centers the study further showed
that optimizing these workloads on AWS
can reduce the associated carbon
footprint by up to
99% aws relentlessly innovates its
infrastructure to build the most secure
reliable and performant cloud for our
customers worldwide with each stop on
our road map AWS works to maximize
resource efficiency while minimizing
waste we continue to enhance our
circular economy strategy which rests on
three core pillars design better operate
longer and recover more this includes
avoiding excess materials enabling
repair and reuse and integrating
recycled content from the start for
example AWS uses 30% recycled or
biio-based plastics in our server rack
components aws has also extended the
lifespan of Amazon Simple Storage
Service S3 hard disks by up to two years
through consolidation of functional
drives and since 2023 over 23 12 million
AWS hardware components have been
recycled or sold on the secondary market
the AWS wellarchchitected framework
helps you build secure high-erforming
resilient and more efficient
infrastructure for a variety of
applications and
workloads the sustainability pillar of
the framework provides a way for you to
measure architecture against
sustainability practices and uncover
areas for improvement while focusing on
reducing the energy consumption of your
workloads the framework includes
questions aimed at helping you evaluate
the design architecture and
implementation of workloads to help
reduce energy consumption and improve
efficiency much more than a simple
checklist it's designed to be a tool
that customers can use to track their
progress towards policies and implement
best practices that support a more
sustainable future in order to meet
sustainability goals and stay compliant
with various regulations customers want
the ability to measure carbon emissions
associated with the usage of AWS cloud
the AWS customer carbon footprint tool
makes it easier to track measure and
review the carbon emissions generated
from your AWS usage it shows your
estimated carbon emissions by AWS region
and select services including EC2 and
S3 here's how it works estimates are
calculated using the greenhouse gas
protocol and are shared in easy to
understand data visualizations if you'd
like to learn more about the highle
methodology or dive deep into the
detailed methodology behind calculations
in the CCFT you can do so in the user
guide the CCFT methodology has been
reviewed and assured by an independent
third-party auditor to access the AWS
customer carbon footprint tool first log
into the AWS management console click
your account name in the top right and
select billing dashboard select the
customer carbon footprint tool in the
left navigation bar under cost and usage
analysis
once you've loaded the customer carbon
footprint tool you will have the option
to set the time periods you want to view
data is delivered once a month and you
can look back at data up to 3 years as
you set your preferred time periods the
dashboard will refresh with the
estimated carbon emissions generated
during that time first you will see your
carbon emissions summary this is your
total carbon footprint in tons of CO2E
or carbon dioxide emissions equivalent
calculated using the greenhouse gas
protocol you can also see the emissions
you have avoided because of AWS
renewable energy purchases in the next
section there are three tabs showing
where your emissions were generated the
first tab shows your emissions over time
the second tab shows your emissions by
AWS service the last tab shows emissions
by AWS region you can click on the
download button on the top right corner
of the customer carbon footprint tool to
download the detailed data as a CSV file
some AWS customers may see changes in
their estimated AWS carbon footprint
over time these changes reflect
adjustments made in the tool to more
accurately estimate customers carbon
footprint from their use of AWS to make
it easier for customers to use the data
from the customer carbon footprint tool
you can also export your carbon data
through AWS's billing and cost
management data export
service the carbon emissions data export
delivers carbon emissions estimates for
all member accounts linked to your
management account when you use AWS
organizations the data export service
automatically delivers monthly updates
in CSV or parquet format to Amazon S3
allowing you to automate the processing
of carbon data for reviews and
dashboards across your entire AWS
organization
with your first export you'll receive up
to 38 months of historical data in your
S3 bucket to allow for historical
analysis to access carbon emissions data
exports log into the AWS management
console choose your account name in the
top right and select billing
dashboard select data exports in the
left navigation bar under cost and usage
analysis
choose create then select standard data
export under export details and give
your data export a name then select
carbon emissions under data table
content settings by default all
available columns will be selected for
your export but you can remove any
columns from the export to reduce the
resulting file size
data export can store data in CSV or
parquet format we recommend you select
parquet because it is a format that can
be stored and queried more efficiently
preserves the data types and columns and
is readable by most big data tools you
can select whether to overwrite existing
data export files or create a new
separate S3 prefix when new data is
available overwriting previous files can
save Amazon S3 storage costs if you
choose to create a new prefix it's
easier to compare new files to previous
ones next select which S3 bucket to
place your data export in and the path
prefix you would like to use for your
files you can also include a tag if you
would like finally click create your
export request will be submitted and you
will be able to see the data within 24
hours in your selected S3 bucket the
first time you request an export we will
deliver historical data for 38 months
subsequent reports will be automatically
generated monthly after the export is
generated in S3 you can load it into a
data analytics tool such as Amazon
Athena or Amazon Redshift to gain
insights into your carbon emissions
